newsitem.title: FRANCE: MEPs demand more funds for cultural heritage.
newsitem.headline: MEPs demand more funds for cultural heritage.

text.p: The European Parliament insisted on Tuesday that the European Union should devote 86 million Ecus over the next four years to protecting and restoring Europe's cultural heritage.

MEPs said they would endorse a programme which will encourage the member states to cooperate on cultural projects but only if EU cultural ministers reverse their decision to axe the scheme's budget to 30 million Ecus.

When they gave the Raphael programme -- COM(95)110 -- a first reading in October 1995, they said the 70-million-Ecu budget originally proposed by the European Commission was insufficient and voted to raise it by more than a third to 96 million Ecus.
Instead of accepting the demand, the Culture Council decided in July to chop the funding by more than 50 percent.

On the advice of Spanish Socialist Francisco Javier Sanz Fernandez, the parliament's rapporteur on Raphael, Euro-MPs voted to reinstate their budget demand, minus the sum of 10 million Ecus, which was spent on pilot projects during 1996.
Since the programme needs the support of both parliament and Council to come into effect, conciliation talks between the two institutions now appear likely.
Sanz Fernandez told Reuters parliament would stick to its guns for three reasons.
"Investments in cultural heritage give European citizens a more positive idea of Europe -- something which is more than the single currency and the internal market," he said.
"Secondly, the programme creates jobs, which is one of the EU's essential goals.
"And thirdly, it promotes cultural tourism in regions which are behind in their economic development."
Rafael should provide funding for four types of project:
- joint preservation projects, such as the restoration of the Parthenon
- exchange of information between professionals working on similar themes
- making cultural heritage more accessible to the public (including using videos and CD-rom, handbooks and multilingual presentations), especially to disadvantaged sectors of society
- cooperation on cultural projects with third countries and international organisations like UNESCO.
